Award.AwardTitle: Math: EAGER: Researching the HyFlex+ Instructional Model of Blended Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As postsecondary enrollments in the United States continue to increase, there is pressure for colleges and universities to provide 21st Century delivery options for courses to accommodate access for a diverse student population, including students who have caregiver responsibilities for children, siblings, or parents; student athletes; students who face commutes that can be dangerous under certain weather conditions or other mobility challenges; and students who become ill. One promising model, first developed by Dr. Brian Beatty at San Francisco State University, is called HyFlex. The primary feature of the HyFlex model is to combine online and face-to-face components ("hybrid") in a single course and allow students to choose when and how they attend class ("flexible"). This project will design, develop, and research the implementation of a HyFlex model in a large introductory statistics course at the University of Michigan. The HyFlex+ introductory statistics course will provide equivalency for students attending class face-to-face or synchronously online by incorporating a backchannel communication system -- a web-based or mobile chat room, like twitter and other social media. In the HyFlex+ model, the backchannel will be monitored by graduate students in order to facilitate real-time conversation among students and the faculty instructor during a class session.

Students, faculty, and institutions are interested in efficient and effective use of resources. Although the HyFlex model has existed for nearly a decade, relatively little research exists about the effectiveness of this model for student learning within higher education. Thus, the core of this proposed research project will be a mixed methods (quantitative and qualitative data collection) study designed to answer pressing questions, including: What are the benefits and challenges of the use of the HyFlex+ model in introductory statistics courses for students and for the institution? What are the costs of the HyFlex+ instructional model on the instructor's and graduate teaching assistants' time? What aspects of the HyFlex+ model contribute to its success or failure in meeting the needs of students and the institution? Why do students choose the attendance mode they do? Is this choice consistent, or does it vary? Is the backchannel equally effective for students in both attendance modes? How and why or why not? What cognitive and non-cognitive student outcomes are affected by the model and how?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The HyFlex+ (hybrid, flexible with backchannel) instructional model of blended learning/instructional mode gives students a daily choice for how they attend lecture classes. Students can attend in person or synchronously and remotely from a location of their choosing. Students who attend remotely are connected to the instructor and other class members via a backchannel, a web- or text-response system that allows students to ask and answer questions. Students attending in person can also ask questions via the backchannel (in addition to raising their hands in the physical room). The instructor (or an instructional assistant) moderates the backchannel and includes questions that come in via the backchannel in the class meeting. The streaming technology and backchannel provide an equitable learning environment for students, regardless of their attendance mode.

 

To implement HyFlex+ in the classroom, the instructor must establish whether the instructional model meets a need for students. For example, a course that offers students the opportunity to attend any of a number of lectures in person and to watch recordings at a later time might not need the HyFlex+ model. However, a course that is offered in fewer sections to students on multiple parts of a campus that are far apart geographically might be well-served by the HyFlex+ model. The implementation of HyFlex+ at the University of Michigan in Stats 412, a calculus-based probability and statistics course that serves students primarily in data science and the College of Engineering, in addition to several graduate students from programs that require statistics, are well served by the HyFlex+ model. Students in Stats 412 tend to stick to one modality for their lecture attendance, but some use the “Flex” portion of HyFlex+, attending in person most of the time and augmenting with streaming views when class responsibilities change their availability.

 

An instructor who records their lectures and posts them for later viewing should consider that decision very carefully. It has been said that students don’t do optional. With respect to recordings, students sometimes think that they will watch the recording for a course but may then find themselves behind in the class after letting a few recordings join the queue of things yet to do. At some point, it is time-prohibitive for these students to go back to watch the recordings, and they might then remain behind in the course. When recordings were dropped from Stats 412, attendance in person and streaming remotely increased from 26% in Fall 2017 (with 40% planning to watch the recordings) to 60% in Winter 2018. (In Winter 2018, 22% of students enrolled did not report how they attended, so they were considered to be non-attenders for purposes of obtaining the 60% attendance number.)

 

It is important than any instructor working so interdependently with technology make sure that they include Instructional Technology (IT) people in all decisions related to technology. We suggest that the IT person and instructor work together to determine the best streaming option (e.g., a streaming box or a web conference technology) and the best backchannel option (e.g., Poll Everywhere or TopHat). It is important to figure out what will be done if the technology has issues on a particular day—how will students attending remotely access the material if the stream is not working that day. It is unusual that the stream would not work, but it does happen. Miller also suggests that clear expectations be communicated to the students with respect to technology. For example, how will the instructor address student questions that have already been answered at another time or in another place? 

 

HyFlex+ could save institutions money and space in a couple of ways. For example, if 40% of students attend remotely and 20% of students attend in person, then space is needed for only 20% of the enrollment. So, either a smaller physical classroom could be used, thus allowing larger classrooms to be used by other courses (or more students could enroll in the course in the same size classroom). As long as the instructor communicates with students that there are options for attendance and that remote attendance is one of those options and exams are given in alternate rooms or given and proctored electronically, the over-enrollment in the course should not be problematic. Alternatively, if it is required that all students have a seat for the first class meeting, that class meeting could be held in an alternate room or auditorium. If enrollment was increased, instructors and their departments need to make sure the administrative demand of the additional students is taken into account. Simply increasing the size of the class without allowing for the extra administrative efforts that come with an increased number of students can result in unfair overload for the instructor if not compensated for in terms of release time, assistance, or income.
